Package org.forgerock.openam.core.rest.authn.core

Class LoginProcess

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.forgerock.openam.core.rest.authn.core.LoginProcess
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    CompletedLoginProcess
    public class LoginProcess
extends Object
    This class represents the login process, maintaining the current state of the login process and providing operations to continue to the next stage of the login process to the completion of the login process. This class is stateless and uses the AuthContextLocal to provide any state required. Therefore a LoginProcess object can be created on a per request basis, as long as the underlying AuthContextLocal is provided.

      Returns the success url from the underlying authcontext
      boolean isFailed()  
      boolean isSuccessful()
      Returns true if the outcome of the login process is SUCCESS.
      LoginProcess next​(Callback[] callbacks)
      Moves the login process to the next step, which means either submitting the callbacks or if the AuthIndexType is LEVEL or COMPOSITE then instead of submitting the callbacks, the callbacks are assumed to be the authentication module choice login step and the resulting choice will be used to continue the login process.

    • Constructor Detail

      • LoginProcess

        public LoginProcess​(LoginAuthenticator loginAuthenticator,
                    LoginConfiguration loginConfiguration,
                    AuthenticationContext authContext,
                    CoreServicesWrapper coreServicesWrapper)
        Constructs an instance of the LoginProcess.
        Parameters:
        loginAuthenticator - An instance of the LoginAuthenticator.
        loginConfiguration - The LoginConfiguration object used to start the login process.
        authContext - The underlying AuthContextLocal object wrapped as a AuthContextLocalWrapper.
        coreServicesWrapper - An instance of the CoreServicesWrapper.

    • Method Detail

      • getLoginStage

        public LoginStage getLoginStage()
        Returns the LoginStage representing whether the login process still requires callbacks to be submitted or has finished with a status define in AuthContext.Status.
        Returns:
        The login stage.

      • getCallbacks

        public Callback[] getCallbacks()
        Returns the array of Callbacks for the current step in the login process.
        Returns:
        The array of Callbacks.

      • getPagePropertiesCallback

        public PagePropertiesCallback getPagePropertiesCallback()
        Returns the PagePropertiesCallback from the current array of Callbacks. If no PagePropertiesCallback exists then null is returned.
        Returns:
        The PagePropertiesCallback or null.

      • next

        public LoginProcess next​(Callback[] callbacks)
                  throws AuthLoginException
        Moves the login process to the next step, which means either submitting the callbacks or if the AuthIndexType is LEVEL or COMPOSITE then instead of submitting the callbacks, the callbacks are assumed to be the authentication module choice login step and the resulting choice will be used to continue the login process.
        Parameters:
        callbacks - The array of Callbacks to process.
        Returns:
        The LoginProcess to use to continue the login process.
        Throws:
        AuthLoginException - If there is a problem processing the login.

      • isSuccessful

        public boolean isSuccessful()
        Returns true if the outcome of the login process is SUCCESS.
        Returns:
        If the login process was successful.

      • cleanup

        public void cleanup()
        Perform any necessary session cleanup after authentication has completed. In the case of successful session upgrade, this will destroy the original session in favour of the new (upgraded) session. In the case of force-auth mode, this will destroy the new session in favour of the old (now upgraded) session. In the case of authentication failure the new session will always be destroyed. For failed session upgrade, the original session is restored. Otherwise, any existing session is also destroyed on authentication failure.
